linkTarget.anchoringText: The objective of this study is to optimize the water injection of reservoir M1, HN oilfield. This oilfield is located in Ecuadorian Oriente Basin (Fig.1).
According to the sand distribution prediction by seismic (Fig.2), and oil saturation distribution from reservoir simulation (Fig.4), we also consider the structure map and the water source.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Sand Thickness Prediction Map of M1

formatted-caption.caption-text: Sand Thickness Prediction Map of M1

linkTarget.anchoringText: This HN:M1 reservoir started to produce in 1995 (Fig.3). At the beginning, there were only several producers.

From the remaining oil saturation distribution, we can conclude that, in vertical the upper of M1 reservoir is better, and in horizontal, the west of M1 is better. But the geologist also mentioned that, the sand in the upper part is poor, meanwhile the west of M1 has a thin sand (Fig. 4).

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Remaining Oil Saturation in Reservoir M1 (from top to bottom)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Remaining Oil Saturation in Reservoir M1 (from top to bottom)

linkTarget.anchoringText: From the production performance status in 2011 (Fig.5), we can conclude that. Firstly, the watercut of the wells near to the aquifer was high; secondly, there were mainly two parts in the whole reservoir, Area I was low watercut stage area, we should keep the watercut as low as possible, that means to prevent waterflooding was important in this area, and Area II was high watercut stage area, in order to keep the oil production stable, we could increase the liquid since it was flooded out in this area.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Production Performance M1 and Watercut Saturation Distribution in Reservoir

formatted-caption.caption-text: Production Performance M1 and Watercut Saturation Distribution in Reservoir

linkTarget.anchoringText: Comparing all the cases (Fig.6,Fig.7), how much was the total injection rate for reservoir M1 was found out.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: BOPD, Np, WC, Pressure Forecasting Curve of the First 3 Cases

formatted-caption.caption-text: BOPD, Np, WC, Pressure Forecasting Curve of the First 3 Cases

linkTarget.anchoringText: Comparing all the cases (Fig.6,Fig.7), how much was the total injection rate for reservoir M1 was found out.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: BOPD, Np, WC, Pressure Forecasting Curve of the other 3 Cases

formatted-caption.caption-text: BOPD, Np, WC, Pressure Forecasting Curve of the other 3 Cases

linkTarget.anchoringText: From the BOPD and Np curves of cases, with the same total injection rate, 14,000bbl/d, but the injection rate of N4 was higher than that of N25 (Fig.8), we noted that, the cumulative oil production would be higher.
linkTarget.label: Figure 8

image-wrap.caption: Bopd & Np of Cases (of which the Injection Rate of N4 Was Higher Than That of N25)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Bopd & Np of Cases (of which the Injection Rate of N4 Was Higher Than That of N25)

linkTarget.anchoringText: As we can see from Fig.9, the results were excellent. The liquid production rate increased a lot, and the oil production rate increased(the BOPD in December 2011 was 135% of that in May) also, at the same time, the watercut decreased a little both in N and H oilfields. And the pressure increased from 913PSI to 1,697PSI by the end of 2011.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Production Curve of HN:M1(Only the Existing Producers)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Production Curve of HN:M1(Only the Existing Producers)

linkTarget.anchoringText: The streamline simulation results substantially have more value as a reservoir management tool when used in conjunction with traditional reservoir engineering techniques such as standard finite difference simulators (Fig.10).
And H28, H37, H18 and other H field producers are mainly controlled by N4. At the same time, aquifer also has a influence on some producers (Fig.11).

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Controlled Area by N4, N25 and Aquifer

formatted-caption.caption-text: Controlled Area by N4, N25 and Aquifer

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Sand Distribution and Current Production Situation (BLPD/BOPD/Watercut)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Sand Distribution and Current Production Situation (BLPD/BOPD/Watercut)

linkTarget.anchoringText: In HN:M1 reservoir, the main flow paths for N4 and N25 are as in Fig.13. In order to improve the production performance.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Current Main Flow Path for Each Injector

formatted-caption.caption-text: Current Main Flow Path for Each Injector

linkTarget.anchoringText: The flow paths as in Fig.14 are expected. We want to enhance the flow path which is in dash line.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Flow Path Change for N25 (N4 is Shut)
